247.11.text: you come this evening and want to see some

430.03.text: Let me talk a little bit about Space

431.44.text: Physics. Space Physics starts with the

433.10.text: sun. Some of my favorite data ever, this

436.34.text: is from 1611. This is actually data on

438.48.text: sunspots when they first started studying

441.20.text: the sun in detail and they started to

443.43.text: figure out that the sun wasn't a constant

445.41.text: object, but actually varied over time.

447.52.text: Sunspots came and went. You can see

450.77.text: these beautiful pictures, this movie, as

452.97.text: magnetic fields lift off from the sun and

455.07.text: blow out into the space between the

459.88.text: off. It actually produces a million mile

462.30.text: an hour wind we call the Solar Wind that

464.10.text: fills the Solar System, and fills the

466.77.text: Heliosphere. I'll use the term heliosphere

468.05.text: quite a bit. Helios is the Greek word for

470.50.text: the sun. Sphere is the region of influence.

474.27.text: This million mile an hour solar wind gets

475.88.text: blown off all directions in space all the

478.37.text: time. You can see here very beautiful

480.84.text: pictures. The sun is the size of the

482.98.text: circle in the middle, and an occulting

485.51.text: disk to block out the brightness of the

487.96.text: sun. You can see this matter, coming out

489.97.text: from the sun all the time. Large coronal

491.82.text: mass ejections and streamers, things like

496.86.text: When I went to Los Alamos, one of the

500.05.text: things they needed was somebody to do

501.55.text: precision work on a certain kind of

503.45.text: detector that I'd had experience with at

504.98.text: M.I.T. and I got involved in the Ulysses

507.07.text: Mission in 1989. This is the launch of the

509.21.text: Ulysses Mission on the Shuttle. We had

512.56.text: a large upper stage rocket that you can

514.97.text: see there being pushed out of the Shuttle

516.75.text: Bay. Then it actually went up to Jupiter

518.89.text: and used the gravity of Jupiter to swing

520.48.text: around, and fly out of the plane of the

522.53.text: planet, something we call the Ecliptic

524.14.text: Plane, and over the poles of the sun for

525.85.text: the first time. What we discovered was

527.97.text: fascinating. This million mile an hour

529.28.text: solar wind was actually 2 million miles an

532.20.text: hour over the poles of the sun, both the

534.73.text: north pole and the south pole. Nobody had

536.31.text: ever left this ecliptic plane where the

538.34.text: planets are. But what we learned was, at

541.38.text: least around solar minimum, that the wind

543.06.text: was twice as fast over the poles. So what

545.95.text: you see here is the cover of Geophysical

548.15.text: Research Letters. This is one of my papers

550.83.text: that has one of the longest lasting images

554.89.text: in all of Space Physics. What you see

556.90.text: there is a picture of the polar plot of

559.27.text: the solar winds speed. You can see it is a

562.20.text: lot further away from the center, over

564.10.text: the top and the bottom of the sun. It's a

565.97.text: lot closer on the sides, by a factor of 2.

568.71.text: So that's the solar wind speed, and that

570.77.text: is super-posed by what the coronal and

572.63.text: solar structure looks like . It turns out

574.48.text: that these bright things at low latitudes

576.68.text: on the sun called streamers have much

578.76.text: slower solar wind coming out of them,

580.82.text: and the high speed solar wind comes out of

582.73.text: the Polar-Coronal holes on the far North

585.73.text: and South ends. There's more encoded in

587.93.text: that than just that, the red and the blue

589.93.text: gives the field direction, and things like

591.94.text: that. This is sort of typical, for how I've

594.30.text: been able to communicate the field in my

595.87.text: own areas, kind of putting together the

598.71.text: different pieces of knowledge into a single

600.82.text: graphic that you don't, I mean if you are a

602.56.text: Space Physicist, you don't have to read

604.64.text: the caption. You can look at that image

608.85.text: and you get the whole thing. That's the

611.95.text: kind of thing I think my mind has been

613.44.text: well suited for. We've also studied the

617.05.text: earths Magnetosphere. There is a region of

619.24.text: space around the Earth that's dominated

621.12.text: by the magnetic field around the earth.

623.60.text: This solar wind interacts with it. This is

625.95.text: movie, artist's conception of the solar

628.01.text: wind coming in, striking the Earth's

629.70.text: Magnetosphere. It actually couples into the

631.60.text: Magnetic Field, couple energy into the

636.30.text: creates the Aurora Borealis. Actually, this

638.38.text: million mile an hour solar wind has been

640.11.text: coming out from the sun and travelling

641.72.text: all the way from the sun. It comes in,

643.91.text: couples with the magnetic field of Earth,

645.56.text: gets dumped down into our atmosphere,

647.71.text: and makes the Aurora. Thet's why you see

649.35.text: the Aurora. All of that, though, is just

653.72.text: this tiny little piece of what Space

655.87.text: Physics is. Down in the lower right of

657.63.text: this graphic you can see in the box about

659.53.text: how big that is. The Big Picture of Space

662.70.text: Physics is the Heliosphere, this region of

665.40.text: influence of our sun. The solar wind

667.43.text: actually blows out all directions in space

669.18.text: all the time. It inflates a bubble in the

673.89.text: also ionized gas and neutral gas, magnetic

675.92.text: fields, and there is this bubble that is

677.78.text: produced by a sort of pressure balance

680.03.text: between this solar wind on the inside, and

681.60.text: all the stuff on the outside. That makes

684.38.text: an interaction that's really frankly very

686.53.text: important for us. This is the most

694.53.text: electron volts, typical cosmic ray energy.

697.01.text: These are very damaging. There are a bunch

698.40.text: of doctors here, you can imagine 100 MED

702.90.text: matter. It's not a good thing. But

704.87.text: fortunately, the Heliosphere, as you can

706.42.text: see by this graph, basically shields out

708.34.text: about 90% of those galactic cosmic rays.

712.13.text: We are protected in the inner solar system

714.05.text: by this interaction of our Solar Wind at

716.18.text: the edge of the Heliosphere. If it weren't

719.27.text: for that, we really couldn't think about

723.40.text: Certainly we wouldn't be able to go to

724.54.text: Mars. Probably, it would be very different

726.49.text: for our lives here on Earth. There are some

729.69.text: of us who think that this kind of

731.56.text: shielding of our Heliosphere is actually

733.73.text: a requirement for life around stars and

735.93.text: other planets. Just like you need liquid

738.07.text: water, you may actually need the protection

740.02.text: shielding of an astrosphere around another

742.15.text: star. Really very important for all of us.

745.15.text: We know that these things exist around

747.36.text: other stars. These are beautiful pictures

749.19.text: of Astrospheres. The problem is the

750.84.text: interaction here isn't strong enough to

753.62.text: give you bright emissions like this. We

756.14.text: had to find another way to observe our

758.50.text: own Heliosphere. This is how we do it.

762.12.text: The Solar Wind are these individual

763.64.text: protons coming off, solar wind coming off,

768.37.text: between the planets. It gets out to the

771.09.text: outer reaches. It's magnitized, these are

774.20.text: charged particles so they gyrate around

776.05.text: the local magnetic field. But there is

778.42.text: also cold material, neutral atoms coming

781.64.text: in from the interstellar material all the

783.21.text: time. These are the blue things that you

784.97.text: see. Occasionally, an electron hops across

787.48.text: to one of these things that came out of

789.41.text: the sun, and it goes zipping off whatever

791.21.text: direction it was going. A few of those

792.81.text: come back past the planets, come right in

794.94.text: toward the center part of the Solar

796.81.text: System, and can be captured in our

798.85.text: instruments in Earth orbit. This is the

800.85.text: IBEX spacecraft capturing one of these

805.84.text: miles...I like to think of it as the 10

809.82.text: miles from the outer reaches of the

812.30.text: Heliosphere and let's us measure it.

819.63.text: coming in from that great distance. We

829.45.text: spacecraft. These are just some pictures

867.55.text: convince NASA to let you put a rocket on

1003.35.text: field squeezes on it, almost like bungee

1039.06.text: you who are scientists here, you know it's

1040.72.text: hard to publish. You know it's really hard

1074.89.text: On each of your tables, there is a yellow

1096.56.text: There should be enough for everybody to

1098.36.text: have one. Okay....So how does Dave's

1103.14.text: brain really work? This is a lenticular.

1108.21.text: A lenticular allows you to encode multiple

1111.04.text: layers of images on top of each other. And

1114.36.text: if you tilt it back and forth, what you

1116.74.text: see is the different images. There are

1122.76.text: different energy bands, the color indicates

1125.10.text: the intensity of those particles. As you

1128.39.text: tilt it slightly, you see different energy

1130.25.text: bands, and that tells you the energy of

1132.26.text: the particles. What you basically see here

1134.53.text: is what we call a Mollweide projection,

1136.26.text: where we've taken the sphere of space

1137.86.text: looking out around us, and we've opened it

1139.93.text: up and put it on to a flat surface. So this

1147.03.text: energy dimension, and one flux dimension.

1149.65.text: This is a 5 dimensional rendition of our

1153.19.text: data. This is, to the best of my knowledge,

1156.58.text: the first time that space data or any data

1158.83.text: has been encoded onto a lenticular that

1161.20.text: they usually use for sales. People put

1163.41.text: cool things on that -- you know, you could

1165.39.text: be sitting on a beach or something like

1167.07.text: that. But, it's especially cool to make

1169.97.text: 50,000 of these. Actually, I was told that

1171.75.text: when they showed up at NASA, somebody

1173.15.text: rushed several of them over to the White

1174.54.text: House because they wanted the Obama

1176.69.text: daughters to get copies of these and look

1178.74.text: at them. But as a scientist, this is a way

1180.57.text: to encode our data, where we get to look

1182.54.text: at all 5 of these dimensions at once. To

1185.09.text: some extent, this is how my brain works.

1191.74.text: lots of them. I think being Dyslexic can

1195.24.text: make you tough, you know, you use what

1197.66.text: you have. No point in whining about what

1199.66.text: you don't have, you use what you have. I

1201.17.text: think it can make you dedicated and really

1203.61.text: a hard worker. I think it can make you

1205.50.text: very independent. I think it can make you

1208.29.text: say, "I don't care what people say can't

1209.78.text: be done. It doesn't really matter what

1211.36.text: they think can't be done." I think it

1213.99.text: allows you to see the big picture

1215.70.text: sometimes. I think it certainly helped me

1219.69.text: temporally, and in flux and other sorts

1222.36.text: of dimensions. I think it allows a lot

1227.68.text: kind of spirit, at least in some

1230.04.text: Dyslexics. I think it's helped make me a

1233.40.text: lot more collaborative. What I do most of

1236.89.text: the day when I'm not doing what pays the

1238.98.text: bills, when I'm doing the fun part of my

1240.58.text: job, is , I'm at the white board with one

1300.82.text: So, in our case, our journey begins again.

1302.18.text: This is my wonderful family, my wonderful

1303.67.text: wife Rochelle is back there who helped me

1305.73.text: through school and other things my whole

1307.62.text: life, and our 3 wonderful sons, the one in

1310.39.text: the Spurs t-shirt--remember we live in

1313.03.text: San Antonio--the one in the Spurs t-shirt

1315.26.text: is my youngest son, Orion. Severely

1318.07.text: tested at age 6 and they said, well, maybe

1321.05.text: he'll never read at all. Through a lot of

1323.16.text: hard work on his part, and Rochelle's

1325.23.text: part and others, and a lot of

1328.16.text: The other two are sort of divergent

1330.84.text: learners also made it through college.

1332.84.text: So, our journey began again. I never

1336.31.text: actually thought of myself as Dyslexic

1338.08.text: until Orion was tested and diagnosed, and

1341.87.text: then it was like, "Well, of course! Sure...

1344.27.text: that's what I've been doing." So, with

1348.40.text: that, I'm going to end but I want to end

1350.73.text: the way I always end talks that include

1352.71.text: IBEX data, which is with a thanks to all

1355.45.text: of the outstanding men and women who make
